D1.label: Integration Success & Re-Rating
D1.description: Sigma Healthcare executes on growth strategy; earnings accelerate
D1.plain_english: The Sigma-CW merger delivers on its A$100M annual synergy target, creating a vertically integrated pharmacy moat. International expansion (NZ, Ireland, China, Dubai) provides growth optionality. The market re-rates the combined entity as a platform business rather than a low-margin distributor.
D1.what_to_watch: Next earnings result and forward guidance.
D1.upside: Material re-rating if execution surprises to the upside.
D1.risk_plain: If growth disappoints, this narrative weakens.

D2.label: Escrow Overhang Triggers De-Rating
D2.description: Sigma Healthcare delivers steady-state results; valuation holds
D2.plain_english: The release of 5.6 billion escrow shares around August 2026 creates overwhelming selling pressure. CW insiders (Gance family, Mario Verrocchi) hold massive positions with strong incentive to diversify. Damien Gance has already sold ~A$800M in shares post-merger. The stock de-rates 20-30% as supply floods the market.
D2.risk_plain: If the base case is already priced in, limited upside from here.

D3.label: Regulatory & Structural Disruption
D3.description: Sigma Healthcare faces headwinds; earnings or multiples compress
D3.plain_english: PBS reform, Pharmacy Guild opposition, or regulatory changes to pharmacy ownership rules disrupt the CW business model. The government restricts aggressive pharmacy discounting or mandates separation of wholesale and retail pharmacy operations.
D3.what_to_watch: Cost pressures, competitive threats, or macro headwinds.
D3.risk_plain: Material downside if multiple risks crystallise simultaneously.

D4.label: Dominant Platform Winner
D4.description: A structural shift changes the investment case for Sigma Healthcare
D4.plain_english: Sigma-CW becomes the "Costco of pharmacy": dominant scale, vertical integration, and brand power create an unassailable market position. Market share grows beyond 30%, Wagner generics reach 20%+ share, and the platform generates returns well above the current valuation through operating leverage.
D4.what_to_watch: Industry disruption signals and regulatory changes.
D4.upside: See research report for upside scenario detail.
D4.risk_plain: If disruption materialises, prior assumptions become invalid.

big_picture: The Chemist Warehouse merger created Australia's dominant pharmacy platform: ~880+ stores, A$10B in CW retail sales, 35-40% wholesale market share, and a vertically integrated supply chain. But the market has priced this at ~58.6x trailing earnings for what is fundamentally a low-margin retail and distribution business. The defining near-term risk is the 5.6 billion escrow shares releasing around August 2026, which could create massive selling pressure. Morningstar estimates a 219% premium to fair value. Synergy targets have been upgraded from A$60M to A$100M, but integration costs of A$95-105M over 3-4 years offset near-term benefits.
